I feel that maybe the current recipe for smithing templates is perhaps too expensive for some, especially since it’s a cosmetic item that provides no gameplay benefits, which is good that it doesn’t, I’d rather much prefer that it’s just cosmetic but the current recipe to make more is a tad too much. I just don’t see the value for it to just grant cosmetic value. Especially when it comes to players who want an easy and chill experience, find a template, make more and easily deck themselves out in their sense of fashion. I feel like the reward and value comes with having to find them in their respective structures, especially since some are rarer than others, once a player finds them, they should be able to feel like “yes! Now I can decorate my armor” instead of “neat, now I just need loads more diamonds” some ppl say it’s good that it’s expensive because some ppl have loads of diamonds around, but if there were a feature to fill in the gap of using diamonds, I think it’d rather be something other than simple and fun cosmetic parts. People even say that smithing templates are late game items, which I have to disagree, I feel like almost anything you do in Minecraft is within the players choice, so coming across the templates shouldn’t have to feel late game at all; so I propose a new crafting recipe. Template at the top, 1 diamond in the middle, and 7 of the respective blocks all the way around. This should hopefully still have value while also having some fun.
i think it would be nice if the player could change the color of the armor trim without having to find another Smithing Template of the same style

With all the materials, templates, and armors the player would have to keep in their inventory when using the smithing table, it would be nice if the table had some form of storage or allowed the player to access a storage block adjacent to it.
Would be cool having a trim that lets the trim in your armor glow, like glowing item frames / signs, it could use glow ink, amethyst, echo shards (would be cool have a trim with echo shards), etc.

The basic armor trim tablets seem too rare and expensive. I'd probably never use them early-game in this state, which is kind of heartbreaking. It would be so disappointing to find one in a jungle temple just to hold onto it for 48 hours until you have some decent gear. Or else, a new player might use one of the rarest items in the game on their iron armor just to never see one again.

My suggestion would be to add a durability meter similar to the Elytra's to the tablets. Maybe you can use it 4 times and then it becomes a paperweight until you can repair it with biome-appropriate materials. Some sandstone for the desert temple tablet? Or some purpur blocks for the end city one? This way there's still a tradeoff for when you choose to apply a new trim to your armor, but it isn't such a hefty investment just to have cool cosmetics. I think if this idea were implemented, it could justify the current expensive cost to copy a tablet.

I think the templates in structures that don’t have a lot of chests and/or are super rare (e.g. jungle temples, woodland mansions, pillager outposts) could use some rebalancing so that the chance of finding a template in a structure is roughly the same when compared to other structures, rather than the odds being based on chests.

I’m in favor of making armor trimming expensive (and therefore special), but given they don’t have any sort of gameplay benefit like the netherite upgrade, I think their duplication recipes could be a bit cheaper. Maybe four diamonds with two on each side, or five in the shape of the hopper recipe. Seven is just a bit much for some flexing.

Horse armor trims. It’s a glaring hole in the feature.

I love the idea of using ingots and crystals for coloring, but requiring a whole netherite ingot for black is just prohibitively expensive. Aside from diamonds, all the other materials are renewable and very easy to acquire late-game. I think coal should be used instead. It’s not an ingot or crystal, but it’s still in that family of minable materials and would keep people from having to spend as much on dying an armor set as they would to make a netherite armor set.

I disagree with those who suggest that armor with golden trim pacify piglins, as that would ruin the whole point of the piglin-gold mechanic, namely to make players think about what armor they wear rather than just getting the perfect set that they can wear anywhere.

The trim upgrades are fine, but the netherite upgrade cost is unnecessarily punishing for endgame players coming from older worlds.  It's a huge cost increase with no benefit.  The goal of incentivizing players to stay in diamond is silly; there are totally underutilized armor classes before diamond which need incentive before diamond, and diamond is arguably the cheapest once villagers are achieved unless there is a nerf there as well.  The endgame community has been vocal about reducing friction to the endgame (see all the problems with endgame inventory and how limited building can be with a wide palette), and this change is specifically raising a barrier for endgame players.  The netherite smithing template either needs to cost less (or none) to copy, or netherite needs to have a HUGE buff to offset the increased cost.  I have some ideas on that:

1) Like elytra, netherite should not disappear when broken, but enter a state where it has to be repaired.  This applies to tools and armor.
2) Netherite armor, as it's made of gold, should disable piglin anger
3) Just like the turtle helmet gives 10 seconds of respiration in water, any piece of netherite armor should give 10 seconds of fire resistance 2 in lava.  Not all fire (like blaze) but specifically lava.

i don't feel that there's a good reason why mojang didn't make armor trims for leather armor. by adding armor trims to all armor types except leather, mojang is making leather armor pointless. Adding armor trims would add a lot more customization to armor, as there is no purple or white or orange armor in the game except for dyed leather. its not like this idea doesn't 'make sense' all it is is like iron or diamond wires on leather, so its not like something that couldn't exist in real life.

I think the rarity of finding them is enough "rarity". The diamond cost isnt terribly burdensome, it adds to the incentive to mine.

It might be desirable to somehow include a way to sacrifice a high value item like a shard to have the materials benefits apply to the armor (gold trim pacifies piglins, netherite adds small knockback resistance, diamond adds durability, emerald increases villager stats, etc)

As for the designs themselves, half of them are too similar, and they look greek in design. I understand the texture resolution is limiting, I hope you guys can work your magic and tweak the designs a bit. We could do with a more menacing set.

Pie in the sky request: each template could maybe offer new helmet shapes/designs? Like a sauron helm, crown, circlet, greathelm, etc.

IMO the armor trims are wayyyy too expensive. The excitement of finding one early-game would be severely undercut by the fact that I'm too poor to use it. It'd probably collect dust in an item frame somewhere until I finally get netherite armor, which I think is a shame.

I think it'd be so cool if the armor trims could serve as a visual expression of your adventures throughout your playthrough. In their current state, though, you're discouraged from using the trims for self-expression and encouraged to hold on to them to use as a late-game flex. For most common purposes, you would NEVER see these used on iron or gold armor, at least not by someone who doesnt have resources to burn.

I think a good medium would be to add a durability meter similar to the elytra's to the tablets. You could use them maybe four times before having to repair them at an anvil with Blackstone or netherrack or whatever. This would still provide a tradeoff of XP for deciding to use the design, but it won't have the ridiculous downside of permanently trashing your rare and valuable item if used early on.

The Netherite Upgrading Option Also Seems Expensive, But Not Nearly Quite As Much Considering The Importance Of Netherite Gear.
Now, For Suggestions, I Would Suggest The Use Of Bone, Nautilus Shells, Scute/Turtle Shells, Prismarine, Purpur, And Possibly Echo Shards As Other Armor Trim Options. Bone Being Similar To Quartz Color-wise, But With Orange Yellow Undertones, Scute Being A Darker Green Than Emerald, Nautilus Shells Being A Nice Orange And Cream Color Scheme, And Purpur Being A Pinker One. Prismarine And Echo Shards Could Possibly Be Animated Like The Blocks/Items Themselves, Slowly Changing Hues And Twinkling, Altho That Might Be Too Much Work For Such A Small Addition, Assuming It's Possible At All. Other Suggestions Would Be Weapon Trims For Swords And Axes, And Horse Armor Trims (possibly being found in villages?) As Others Have Suggested As Well.

I suggest making it so when a player obtains a template or crafts a design, they "learn" it and can make them provided they have the materials.

I neeeeed customization

The templates remind me of runes. Add a tab to the smithing table with slots. When you obtain a template, put it into your smithing table. This "consumes" the template, imbuing the table with the ability to create as many of that type as you want. You can see your progression and which "runes" you need looking at the table. This progression is unique to you and any other player that interacts with the table will only see their progression (like an Enderchest). This applies to any smithing table you craft (or not!)

People who want a specific set but arent interested in hunting for it can commission pieces from other players instead. Progression is purely up to the player. No risk of mistakes or misapplied templates (you can still risk dying and dropping a template on your way to insert it into the table).

I dont find the idea of adding things solely to consume our glut of items a very compelling gameplay challenge. Sooner or later you'll end up with a surplus of any given item. Sustainability is always the better option.

I think that glow ink and echo shards should be a trim as well, like glow ink making the trim glow and the echo shards making the trim sparkle. I also think the diamond price for duplicating a template is too expensive, maybe 4 diamonds instead. Otherwise, good feature.

I like the idea of the trims, but if they are purely decorative, they shouldn't be this costly. The trim templates shouldn't be consumed, in my opinion. I would like to see additional colours available (i.e. more additive material options). Weapons and tools with trims could also be useful. If the trims themselves provided benefits then the consumption of the templates would be understandable, but reducing the cost to duplicate would be a happy medium.

I don't truly understand or agree with the rationale behind making netherite upgrades more difficult than they currently are. Perhaps increasing the benefits of using netherite would be a fair trade-off. Otherwise I can see it putting players off from making the effort/paying the cost, since losing all your upgraded armour/tools to the void or despawn after death is always a risk.

I think duplicating trim is currently way too expensive for a purely cosmetic change. I think using amethyst instead of diamonds for the duplication recipe would be better, as amethyst doesn't have many uses, and amethyst is already used to duplicate allays.

While the implications of armor trims are awesome. I can't justify spending a netherite ingot on weaker armor sets just for cosmetic purposes. I.E. copper trim oxidizing or attracting lightning, gold trim making piglins passive, netherite reinforcing weaker armor, etc.

I haven’t tried it out yet cause I don’t have Java, but from what I’ve studied so far, it’s honestly amazing how this is now a feature in the game, and it adds onto the creative, customizable experience to the armory aspect of the game. Though I feel like some things just don’t make sense, as in the adventurous side of this feature. I love almost everything about this but at the same time I feel like if the armor trims were only for cosmetic purposes and as a player that loves survival/adventurous and customization/creative aspects in video games. The way we have to get the trims would be a bit tedious. Though I see what the devs are going for, to make us explore more of the world and actually adventure out to seek these, the percentages of the trims alongside with the rarity of these structures make them a little less worth looking for, especially the stronghold and woodland mansion ones. It’s a good thing to have players continue with playing the game and explore more in their worlds than just as far as the eye can see. It’s also gonna make players feel as if they have to do too much for these things along with the amount of diamonds we have to get to duplicate is also overwhelming with the addition of searching for these in the first place, I know this gives diamonds more use and value, but these should also atleast have like a minor buff to your armor or cool features with the types of ores you use for the armor trim, or again a minor buff to its strength and lifespan.
Let us make animated color palettes for custom materials :)
I think the "Sentry" smiting template should be duplicated with Tuff in the crafting table, not cobblestone. It matches the color more and gives a use for Tuff.

The crafting recipe is a bit too heavy on the diamonds, especially for cosmetics. Instead you could use echo shards. The name corresponds with the idea that you are duplicating the item. They're still rare so exploration is encouraged, and since multiple can be found in one place it makes it easier to make a full set of templates once you do find it.

I think that the new additions are great but expensive. To justify the price, it could be cool if the different materials had very slight buffs (ex: netherite has slight knockback resistance). These should be small enough so that people will still wear different sets, but it would be cool if there was an incentive that isn’t just cosmetic.

Alternatively, the cosmetic trims could also be non-consumable (with the exception of the netherite upgrade), so that something that is just cosmetic isn’t too annoying to get.

Another thing to note is that because netherite is more expensive, it should be buffed very slightly overall (ex: netherite pickaxe can instamine deepslate with haste 2).

Overall this system is awesome and a step in the right direction.

1. The Smithing table is right now a little bit confusing. I think that the slots should be placed in some other kind of way. Like on the top is the new slot and under there should be the old two slots.
2. I know its only for style but some very very small effects would make it more worth to collect them all. Some effects based on the location where you got them from. Like for jungle plus 1 heart or something diffrent.

I think finding them is okay as is, but the diamond cost needs to be toned down, or changed to another resources that needs a use.

Armor trims look good, but as with most things should be able to have glow squid ink or glowstone used to make it glow akin to enderman or spider eyes.

The patterns themselves work okay together sometimes with different patterns on different pieces, but don't always work well together, especially considering differing brightnesses.

Even though it's cosmetic, I think there should be SOME use even if only a select few have them. the trims look really bad on chain armour, it looks extremely cluttered

There needs to be other ways of getting the nether upgrade item that isn't reliant on non-renewable loot chests. For big servers, it means that resource will be depleted quickly, leaving newer players with no chance at ever getting netherite gear. And relying on the kindness of other players in public servers to duplicate the upgrades for you isn't a guarantee, or even likely.

The same things with the trim items, as it is currently, they are more of a grandfather status exclusive to only the oldest players on the server, as the newer players have no chance of obtaining any armor trims. This is less of an issue for the trims though, since they are purely cosmetic.

I think the new "Smithing Template: Netherite Upgrade" should look more molten and feel more like an artifact than have a literal upgrade symbol on it. Nothing else in the game breaks the 4th wall like that so It would be cooler if it looked molten and some diamonds or netherite mixed in the texture.

More material options.

It just should be things that are more easily obtained on my opinion. Especially, ESPECIALLY nerfing the netherite cost.

I think the armor trim templates should be reduced to like 5 or 3 diamonds since they are for cosmetics, while the netherite upgrade stays at 7 diamonds. My response to the questions.

1. Unsure but I think the spawn rate is good.

My ideas.

I think Echo shards should be used to make a dark blue color.

If I have to spend 7 diamonds every time I apply a pattern it becomes a bit difficult to be creative with them. There is a lot of trial and error involved in this in order to achieve a good combination.

The UI on the smithing table definitely needs to be a bit more clear. The animations are a good way of explaining where everything goes but I feel as though the template box should be separated from the other boxes.

Other than that I love them and I hope this means that there will be a similar focus on exploring and unique uses for biomes in the future.

I really REALLY want to be able to layer trims on top of the same piece of equipment, like designs on a banner. I think it would be really a cool and the possible combinations would really feel endless!

As a peaceful mode player, I'm excited that most of these will be obtainable, but why is the tide armor trim template not found in ocean ruin chests? If it's a matter of ocean ruins being too common, could they just be added to chests in big ruins? I can understand giving easy - hard difficulty players additional reasons to go to ocean monuments, but I don't see why the template couldn't also go into ocean ruin chests.

The diamond requirement for duplicating templates does make them feel more valuable, but I agree with the suggestion of others that instead of requiring 7 diamonds and 1 block (netherrack, cobblestone, etc.), it should be swapped for 7 blocks and 1 diamond, especially since that seems to more closely resemble the icons for the templates.

I like that the armor trim templates are rare and desireable loot without just being "enchanted gear but stronger" and that older structures are getting loot that makes them worth looking for. I think the chances of getting trims in a chest should be more proportional to the rarity of the structure and the number of chests they contain. Obviously more trims from more places would be nice in the future. Prismarine and glow ink as trim materials would be neat.

I see lots of people asking for gold trims to pacify piglins, but what about making the netherite trim cause your items to become fire/lava proof? This change would only serve one use, and thats to keep the items themselves which you have worked hard for safe from destruction
Note on the GUI for the blacksmith's table: a pure standing armor stand looks unnatural. It should be in the black square like a player or a horse in an inventory.

The mechanics for finding smithing templates is excellent. With this addition, almost every structure in the game has been elevated with a new, unique, item. Exploration has benefits again!

Diamonds are something that, unless you are on a server with an economy, that I just ignore at this point. This gives diamonds a use again, and I think the price is pretty close to right.

A few improvements this mechanic would be:
(1) a series of a buffs to armor that is related to either the trim material or/and trim design or/and armor piece. For example, an armor set fully trimmed in gold could prevent piglins from being angered.
(2) Add echo shards / eye of the sea as a potential trim materials.

  • In improvement 1 above, a fully trimmed echo shard armor set could provide the ability to have the warden not be able to hear your individual movements allowing you more mobility when in ancient cities.
  • An eye of the sea trimmed turtle helmet could provide improved / infinite underwater breathing. 

Based on those changes, some less used items to the game would receive some more love and attention, and the added personal choice could also have small boosts towards how we set up armor and reward us for making multiple sets.

Maybe with what the crafting recipe is for the smithing templates and how pricy it, maybe have the recipe changed to 1 template 4 diamonds and 4 of the respective corresponding blocks and it gives 3 in return. [block] [diamond] [block]

I like the new armor trimming feature and searching for various smithing templates will be fun. But using the same feature to craft netherite armor feels needlessly complicated, inelegant, irrelevant, and hard to remember.

There are other ways to make netherite armor more valuable and rare, namely by raising the price. Allow players to craft netherite armor the same way they craft gold and iron armor, by using ingots. And use a crafting bench to make netherite armor, not a smithing table.

Yes, netherite armor will be much more expensive this way. But isn't that the point?

By requiring players to conquer multiple bastions with piglin brutes in order to get a full set of netherite armor you're not making the armor harder to get, you're dissuading many players from ever trying to do that. Reward players who are persistent enough to mine a lot of ancient debris, at the same rate of four netherite scraps to an ingot, by letting them earn the best armor in the game through hard work.

I believe that each type of ore that’s used for the trim should have more to it then an aesthetic feel. Each ore type used as trim on a piece of armor should have different effects and perks to them. Iron trim should have the ability to heal surrounding iron golems. Gold trim could grant you the ability to keep friendly with the piglins. Emeralds could grant you the ability to have villagers follow you if wanted, and maybe even give a slight discount to trades. Diamond could give you give you half a point more durability and netherite could give you a one whole point more durability. Lapis could give you good luck for getting the more rare enchantments. Red stone could grant you longer and stronger portion effects upon drinking them. Copper could grant the ability to harness lightning giving the player a charged effect. The player will have one chance at choosing when and where they will be summoning lightning around them, which will give surrounding players and hostile mobs an electric shock. Amethyst will grant a new effect as well as quartz.

Hey! I just wanted to touch on some things!

-The interface feels really nice. Reminds me of the anvil interface, and it feels like it really fits with the theming of the crafting interfaces.

-The thing that I would like to see the most is an additional slot in the interface to add glow ink to armor trimming. If adding another slot would not be the right way to proceed with it, I could see a system where an armor piece is gilded, and then added back into the smithing table menu with a glow ink sac (or echo shard) to cause the gilding to glow. This process would be similar to how potions interact with redstone, glowstone, gunpowder, or dragon's breath in that the ingredients are added back into their crafting interface to be modified.

- In addition, I could see an option to remove the coating by placing the armor item in a crafting menu with an axe, removing the gilding at the cost of some of the armor and axe's durability. This would be similar to the way that axes are used to remove wax from copper blocks.

-The only other comment I have is that many of the boot items feel very similar. With the restrictions of the small texture area, would it be possible to change some of the similar boot patterns to something that stands out just a bit more from the others?

So while I feel in Singleplayer worlds and on multiplayer servers that reset regularly this is a fine change, there is a massive barrier for those of us who run public servers which don't reset often, if at all. Smithing Templates as aesthetic pieces are fine, but Netherite Upgrade Templates are often going to be extremely difficult to obtain as the nether is very well explored and widely looted. A simple fix for these communities to this would see Netherite Upgrade Templates craftable with Netherite Scraps and some other ingredients; I would propose 6 scrap, 2 gold ingots and 1 magma cream. Alternatively, bringing down the cost of duplicating only Netherite Upgrade Templates, perhaps to 4 dia and 3 netherrack or 3 dia and 4 netherrack.

There should be a way to un-trim armor so u can change to whatever trims u want, you could add a new functionality to the grindstone to remove trims!

I feel like applying a trim should give a very minor durability boost and perhaps provide a small knockback resistance when applied to non-netherite armor.

Currently, there's not actually much reason to use trims in normal survival unless the player is very rich already- so having some sort of small buff from applying trims would be nice. Taking it to the next level, perhaps a separate buff for each type?

Here are some of the ideas I came up with, but of course they're probably very unbalanced, just things that can give you an idea of what I mean. And of course perhaps it's just the expensive ones that give buffs-

  • Iron = More durrability
  • Copper = Makes the player more likely to be struck by lightning, but also gives minor knockback resistance
  • Lapis = Also makes it cheaper to apply enchants
  • Gold = Makes it cheaper to apply enchants to the item (no piglin stuff)
  • Diamond = +1 armor toughness
  • Emerald = Villages will give a very minor discount
  • Redstone = Potions effects (positive and negative) will last slightly longer
  • Amethyst = Cosmetic only
  • Quartz = Reduced durability by 10%, +1 armor toughness
  • Netherite = Knockback resistance, +1 armor toughness, and increased durability (netherite is still expensive)

Overall these are fantastic but we should be able to use these for #1 horse armor #2 elytra and may be even tools and other things. This is definitly something that can be built on alot!

I would also love if glowsquid ink could be used to make the trims glow, that would really make that sought after resource

PLEASE, leave the price of copying templates this high. Diamonds are basically useless once you’ve got the whole gear and a mending villager. Also agree with some others who suggest adding buffs to the armor with trimming material, at least for gold(piglins will not attack you) and netherite(will not burn), so then the price will be even more reasonable

I think the textures of the templates could be improved. Right now they look to elaborate and don't fit in with other textures in the game in my opinion. I think the patterns/ shapes on them look too contrasted to the rest of minecrafts textures. I feel like these could be smoothed out or even replaced with a general texture used by all of them but with different colors to match the structure that they are from. The netherite upgrading one specifically does not look like it could go in a bastion chest, especially with a the blue arrow. I think the arrow looks a little cheesy and not like something that would be created by ancient nether creatures. given the ancient status of netherite, I think that the template should look its part. This example is just for the netherite one, but I think all of them could use the same advice. I think the "Dune", "Tide", and "Rib" templates do a good job and have good variation whereas the "Ward", "Sentry", and "Snout" dont quite work with their limited resolution. Otherwise I think the concept of them is a very good place to start adding more incentives to exploration.

Most of the armor trims look amazing, there's something for everyone! There is limitless potential for customizability.

Regarding the issue of duplicating the Smithing Templates, the expense makes them feel special, but not rare. There are two solutions I can think of to remedy this:

1) Giving the armor trimming a functional purpose (depending on material) could make the expense of duplicating worth it.

2) Making Smithing Templates non-consumable (like banner patterns). To offset this, the frequency of them appearing in loot chests could be reduced. This could make them feel more unique, like the beloved music discs.

The Smithing Table feels intuitive, but the netherite upgrade system may be confusing to newer players. The additional item required to upgrade gear may deter players from doing so, as it is already expensive and many might feel netherite isn't worth the cost (when one could craft several diamond items with what is required to craft the Templates). Furthermore, players playing on older worlds have potentially already raided nearby bastions in their world, making it even harder to create new netherite items.

Overall, the concept of armor trimming is wonderful. The increased functionality of the smithing table is well-deserved, but perhaps there is a way to increase the reward for the player.

it doesnt feel like it has any applied storytelling features for singleplayer

having the template itself structure how much extra durable an armor set can be useful especially if one day the templates can be stacked (you can be swarn to two factions and be a mediary between them)

having most of the templates be in bastions make sense relative to minecraft legends but have no tie in making our own story as plenty of people have yet to even access the nether because the block gradients arent worth the risks and having templates be end game exclusive will make the event of finding and using one less impactful. especially if it doesnt garuntee any gameplay change.

there is also alot of talk about making trims do stuff and I think redstone producing more power the more you wear trimmed with it could be useful for different contraptions (ie. shifting on a line of redstone would make a current spreading from where you stand, opening trapped chests negates activation, and opening hoppers stops items from transfering until closed)

I would like to add that the trims should not have extra effects. I have seen some suggestions here that a specific trim or added material should add effects like speed, fireresist or neutrality to piglins, even if it’s a minor effect. And it might sound cool or that it gives it more purpose, But..

One thing that I hate about armor in games is: when I try to make it look good and cool, and look the way I want it to look, but if I do that I lose out on a good effect. So then it becomes a meta that the only good armor trim is the dune trim with gold and then everyone uses only that trim and everyone looks the same again.

It should only be about looks. Then I can make it look the way I want it to look without worrying about the additional effects messing with my artistic expression.

I don't feel that crafting the templates is particularly expensive. If it's to be adjusted at all, it would only be by one or two diamonds less. Once you have a set of diamond armor and tools, you barely have a use for them and they only see significant use with diamond economies on multiplayer. For those who don't have resources, or hate mining, it's good that they have the option of adventuring for more templates. This encourages mixing and matching as well.

With the current setup, I am very glad that the upgrade template is able to be duplicated, because if it didn't, you would have a horrible problem on servers where they would charge exorbitant prices for an item that is for important gameplay progression. Basically, imagine having nether wart that you can't grow more of and could only harvest from a fortress. How often do you think you would find it? People would be more likely to hoard their excess than sell it.

TLDR: Great feature; getting and using templates could be discouragingly expensive, and the colors could be more balanced in terms of cost. 

Armour Trims would be a fantastic feature that add a good, usable way to customize armor. Acquiring templates encourages interested players to explore many different structures while allowing those not keen to continue progression without obstruction.

However, the current implementation seems to be a bit unbalanced. The rarity of these templates along with their high duplication expense will definitely limit experimentation, especially for casual players. Most players who want to dabble in these would probably want/have to wait till end-game. They would not want to "waste" the templates on lower-level armor such as iron and potentially diamond. This, while well-intentioned, is likely to lead to low usage.

Another area of imbalance is the trim colors. The different colors are purely cosmetic and depend highly on players' preferences. It therefore makes little sense to make some colors very cheap (quartz, iron), while others extremely expensive (diamond, netherite). The varying costs cause some colors to be more "exclusive" than others: wouldn't it be better to have all ingredients at a similar cost?

Overall, greatly looking forward to incorporating these changes into a long-term world and hoping for some re-balancing modifications. Huge kudos to the design and dev teams!

My thoughts:
They're awesome. I love the idea of decorative elements for armor, it's something that Minecraft has needed for a while now. That being said, I have some critiques, and some feedback.

  • Templates are too expensive. Reducing the cost to 1 diamond instead of 7 and making the recipe shapeless would still be a good cost while making them FAR more worthwhile to copy. Alternatively, they could just be tools, and not be consumed on use. 
  • Things that should be considered valid trim materials: blaze rods (fiery orange trim), prismarine crystals (light teal/prismarine trim), echo shards (speckled sculk-colored trim), ender pearls (deep teal trim), and glowstone dust (pale gold trim, glows by default). 
  • You should be able to apply glow ink to trimmed armor for an effect similar to the glow squid, glow signs or magma blocks (the trim appears to "glow" in the dark). 
  • Some smithing materials should have special effects. For example, gold trim could pacify piglins. Echo shard trim could reduce sculk sensor/warden detection radius. Blaze rod trim could give limited fire immunity. Netherite trim could give a limited amount of armor toughness. 
  • Trims need to be also applicable to tools. If each trim makes the tool take on a unique shape and color pattern, all of a sudden there's so many more things for mapmakers and datapack makers to work with. So please, if there's just one feature I could add, it would be "trims on tools". That would be perfect.
Regarding armors: Maybe also consider updating the older armor textures to somewhat match the netherite set? Trims currently look a little odd on the existing sets.
There should be a way to remove trims if you dont want them anymore. Not expecting to get the materials back but it would be a nice small change.

Answering the specific questions: 

  • As of right now it feels a little too challenging for the reward. 
  • Yes, absolutely it does. It's fun to go look for them, but there needs to be a better adventuring system rather than just stumbling blindly about.
  • No, it just makes them feel expensive. Instead of a lot of diamonds, each one should use a diamond, a base material, and a gem/crystal/item specific to the "area" the trim is supposed to be from. For example, the Eye trim could use an ender pearl, the Coast trim could use a Heart of the Sea, the Tide trim could use prismarine crystals, etc.
  • Somewhat. If you could allow us to trim an entire set at one time so we could see what the finished set looks like before finalizing, that would be perfect.
  • I love them, but some of them look out of place on the older armor textures (basically everything except netherite). I'd recommend updating most of the armor textures.
  • Yes, absolutely.

1) Material Specific Templates
2) Template Durability instead of duplication

Once acquired the empty template could be crafted into an armor specific material using 8 of your chosen armor material (gold ingots, iron ingots, etc.)

Example Scenario:

  • 1. Find the snout template in bastion remnants
  • 2. Combine a snout template and 8 gold ingots to receive a golden snout template.
  • 3. Place your golden snout template, gold armor, and desired trim material on the smithing table.
  • 4. Craft your golden armor with snout trim.
  • 5. Receive back your original snout template (without the gold)

After a few cycles of this process, the snout template could break, requiring the player to repair it on the crafting table.

A lot of people are talking about why Gold Armor Trims should pacify Piglins. However, if this is implemented, there need to be other incentives for different materials. My solution to this is:

Netherite Trims: Extra armor points.
Diamond Trims: Less extra armor points.
Iron Trims: A small amount of extra armor points. 
Gold Trims: Instead of pacifying Piglins, offer added enchantability.
Copper Trims: Oxidize over time, with Honeycomb used in the Smithing Table to wax the armor.
Quartz Trims: Trigger traps, but in a special way that does not allow Observers or Comparators to detect them.
Amethyst Trims: Play Amethyst sounds whenever a player walks.
Emerald Trims: Add discounts to Villager trading. The more armor trims, the better the discount.
Redstone Trims: Slightly extend potion effects.
Lapis Trims: Can be used in place of 1 Lapis Lazuli in the Enchantment Table.

Secondly the high diamond cost of the trims makes it infeasible for use in early game. and so the customization despite being an option for adding trims to iron, chainmail, and gold armor sets will not be used by players with these tool sets because it is too expensive. In this way the cost of duplicating the patterns makes the system only allow the individual expression and customization that the 1.20 update focuses on en end game option rather than promoting individual expression throughout people's playtime.

One option that seems like a good idea to reduce the cost of using the trims while still maintaining the patterns as 'these are special items you can get in a similar difficulty by exploring or duplicating' is to make patterns usable multiple times but take durability. (and they could be repaired in an anvil using diamonds?) Durability could even be set to something low such as breaking after 5 armor pieces. this way there is still an incentive to clone and repair but reducing the barrier to use.

Addressing the 6 requested questions:

1. It is rewarding to find templates, though the spawning rates could be tweaked. The rib, snout, eye, spire, vex, ward, and wild templates should have their spawn rates increased due to the rarity of their structures. 

2. Yes

3. The copying mechanic of armor trimming doesn't make them feel rare but incredibly tedious to obtain. While diamonds now have a late-game use, the expense of copying the templates incentivizes fewer players to actually use this feature. Just make them the armor equivalent of banner patterns. 

last 3 questions: Yes

Armor trims were announced on snapshot 23w04a for Java edition. Now, imagine if when you trimmed your armor with different ores You got certain effects. It doesnt necessarily have to be effects like the ones given by potions, that would be too overpowered. Maybe certain types of trims could give you boosts based on what the ore you are using does by itself. For example, maybe gold trimmed armor lowers the range hostile piglins see you on, or gives better odds on bartering. Maybe emerald armor makes villagers respect you more, or redstone armor powers the block bellow you. It could also be more cosmetic effects, like amethist armor making sound when you walk like when you do it on amethist blocks. Maybe iron trimmed armor increases the protection number it gives you by a bit, or netherite trims make it survive lava. Maybe combining different trims on your four slots combines the effects but makes them weaker to balance them, and using the whole set with the same type of trim increases the effect. This could give an enormous amount of depth to the armor system.

This might be too much for a niche feature, but I prefer simpler patterns that can be combined, more like banner patterns.

It would also be interesting if some patterns could be used in the dyes to give a wider variety of colours. On our Minecraft server, certain players are associated with quite vivid colours, and amethyst and copper trims are not quite right for this (quite possible some other ones as well)
If you ask me, you should be able to trim armor with the same material as the armor itself (I used commands to see how they look with the same material, and they look pretty neat!)

• How challenging is it to find Smithing Templates, and is it rewarding?

Some of the Templates are far too challenging and not rewarding enough. Many players will want 1 of each, as collectors, but realistically that means generating thousands of chunks, just searching for the Vex Template, which is the worst imo in terms of chance per chest, amount of chests per structure and rarity of the structure. 

  • Does searching the world for Smithing Templates feel adventurous?

It feels adventurous until you get tired of searching and load up a seed finder, rendering the adventure and exploration meaningless.

  • Do the diamond requirements for copying Smithing Templates make them feel rare or special?

No. It makes it feel like a grind. Which is neither rare nor special. But is probably still the best way of making them attainable outside of finding more.

  • Does applying armor trims with the redesigned Smithing Table feel intuitive?

It's hard to know what feels intuitive when you read a blogpost about the feature and don't have to figure it out on your own.

  • How do armor trims look visually?

They look good, although some of them are incredibly similar to one another. For example Coast and Sentry on the helmet is a couple pixels of difference.

  • Are you able to be creative when combining different types of patterns on separate armor pieces?

Of course you're able to be creative with different types of patterns. But, you would usually use the same material for the trim as the rest of your gear as a highlight

ex:

As a purely cosmetic item the cost is too great and locating these templates is too rare. The change to creating netherite makes it not worth going after anymore. Without this change making me more powerful in the game there is no point. At first glance this was fantastic and I was excited. Then came the finding of the templates that isn’t guaranteed and the amount of diamonds required. This isn’t Hermitcraft. We all aren’t spending our entire days mining in a diamond block war.

I love the concept of Armor Trims, being able to customize armor is great and I love how it encourages people to explore and find structures. I personally love exploring the world already but there wasn't a lot of unique loot that gave me a reason to keep exploring, I liked finding Buried Treasure but I can't even use all of the Hearts of the Sea I find. But with these templates, I have a reason to explore and complete every single structure and dungeon.

I do think some of them need to be a bit more visually distinct, especially with some of the Legging and Boot Armor Trims (except for the Rib and Vex Armor Trim Designs, I think they're perfect).

For the price of copying them, I think instead of using diamonds maybe we should be able to craft or find an empty Template that we can copy the armor Template onto. If not, I think diamonds are fine, since it encourages people to explore more. 

My only suggestion now is to have Trimmed Armor appear as rare loot (even more rare than the armor templates), I think that would complete the mechanic as a whole and effectively doubling the amount of loot you can find. I feel like players don't have a reason to use armor they find in structures, especially since some of them are cursed, but I feel like they would if some of them were trimmed armor, even if the trimmed armor was cursed.

Like I said, I love this new addition to Minecraft. In a single snapshot, I feel like it has already added a lot to the game. I can't wait to see what's next!

The textures of trims should be customizable per tier of armor so that making custom armor in resource packs is easier.

There would be one folder for each tier (chainmail, iron, gold, diamond and netherite). This would prevent custom accessories added to the base layer of armor through resource packs becoming over-layered by trims.

This would also give resource pack/datapack creators even more flexibility with trims.

Sometimes, no matter how careful you are, you die and loose everything in Minecraft, all your tools and armor. That is part of the game. It's a painful process and a hard loss, of many hours depending on what backup supplies you have available and the set up of your world. It is, to me one of the most frustrating moments of the game, that rather than going on to build what excites me or play with friends I now have to spend hours getting replacement materials, (diamonds, levels, netherite, enchanted books, a new elytra).

The increased costs to my armor and tools do not make them feel special to me, it simply makes that already frustrating process longer and harder. Any minimal amount that it make netherite feel like a bigger moment or achievement the first time around is entirely negated by how much extra time it is going to be second time around, and the third. 

Furthermore, armor templates current state punishes players on less informed servers. I certainly play on many servers with players who don't pour over the update log or know every detail of the update. That a Smithing Template needs to be copied, or even can be copied is going to be lost on a lot of people, or deemed not worth the extra expenditure of their diamonds.

Please make it so templates enter a "broken" state when used (like the elytra when it runs out of durability) and make it so they need to be repaired with diamonds when broken, instead of needing to copy it before usage if you want to keep it. This would make armour trims more feasible to use early-game and make it so people use them more often, because players won't have to worry about getting enough diamonds to copy a trim before using it. Needing to repair trims instead of copying them would also make them more valuable/rare (in the sense that there can't exist more trims than there already was in your world upon generation), because you won't be able to make as many as you like.

Armor Trims is just a gateway to more fabulous customization ideas like maybe custom designs for wielding tools, reminds me of Minecraft Dungeons Designs, to be honest. An Awesome idea really, and maybe we can do something with hide and and various types of Leather armor like from a Wolf or even Sheep Armor which gives it a furry effect, even if it gives no real perks like extra warmth in the cold.

This feature has a lot of promise. I think it has already been said, but this is the perfect opportunity to implement custom armor model support for Java edition via resource/datapack. As it stands right now you can change textures of custom armor trims but not models--please expand that functionality!

Flipside of that, I love that you can use trims to change the textures and models of other items via resource/datapack, but it doesn't seem to be linked to which trim pattern you use, only the material. Please make it so that items can be trimmed in a pattern-specific way, so that we can have a convenient way to create custom, hard-to-obtain item models, that aren't just smithable with any old trim you find laying around somewhere, and can still also have dynamic colored texture elements based on the smithing material. The datapack potential behind item trims that are only obtainable via patterns with custom crafting recipes / loot tables is almost infinite.
This is a good opportunity to add the trim removal option for the grindstone, and/or possibly rewamp the grindstone along the way, because nobody really uses it for repairs.

Many people have expressed concerns over netherite smithing template availability on multiplayer servers. Since netherite upgrades are part of game progression, rather than cosmetic upgrades, I suggest adding some kind of mob (something like a pigeon brute wearing gold armor with a snout netherite trim) that has a low, recurrent chance of spawning in a bastion, with a low chance at dropping the netherite upgrade.

This way, players are still required to find a bastion, but have a low chance to still find a netherite template even if the bastion has already been looted.

We can have a better system that allows players more granular control over what they want, still be balanced and offer incentives for exploring and resource management.

Instead of templates, have a Hammer drop from Brutes or be found in bastion chests. Having this hammer equipped will allow the player to interact with the Smithing table for armor design.

The design system should be similar to the banner system, offering a wide variety of simple designs unique to each type of armor piece, with a similar limit like the banners six.

No two armors will ever be the same, and the player will feel like they smithed something special.

Instead of copying templates or risk losing them and not being able to trim *at all*, players can spend Blaze Powder plus the desired material.

You still have to progress, explore, spend valuable materials, grind for powder, and the hammer is finite and must be earned and cant be farmed. All this and the player can still have fun with the feature and even make sets to place on stands without being overwhelmed with grinding, and its *actually* expressive and allows the player full customization.

Oh, and the Hammer? It can be used as a (slightly ineffective) weapon. How cool is that?

Ultimately, I feel that armor trims, as a feature, seem extraneous. Why is something that is purely cosmetic so expensive in game? Is it just to be used as a trophy? 0 functionality on a feature that seems to be the core idea of an update feels off. I understand that it's difficult to strike a ballance between "cool and unique" and "everyone has more of these than they'll ever use". But I have a feeling that this feature will eventually become one that people rarely interact with.

To that end, it would be foolish of me to complain without offering solutions. In the case of armor trim, it may be finding a way to better implement it into the gameplay loop. As of now it feels like an afterthought. Perhaps slight buffs depending on the trim used. Lapis decreases the cost of enchanting, gold calms piglins ect. Without anything motivating the acquisition of these items, they feel like another thing to clutter your inventory. Which is another problem all together.

I think it would be cool if armor trims were adjusted on a per-armor basis, like a durability system. For the tough armor like diamond or netherite it would make sense that the armor trim would take a beating and break, but it seems they should not be consumed for the weaker armor like leather since they break really fast. That way they are still rewarding to find, but allow players to use it more where they see fit without being penalized and only really making it expensive for use cases where it would be for their normal armor to wear. Possibly mid-tier armor could do something like damage the trim, causing it to need repair, or else it would break, allowing for better mid-game customization without such a high cost.

I think it's a pretty common consensus that the trim duplication recipe is a bit on the pricey side, and makes using trims on more common armor not necessarily feel like it's worth the cost. As such my suggestion is to allow other materials to be used to duplicate templates, but only allow the duplicate templates to be used on armor of matching or lesser quality. For example, a duplicate template made using iron ingots could be applied to iron, gold, chainmail or leather armor, but not to diamond or netherite armor. Likewise, using gold ingots would allow the template to be used on gold, chainmail or leather armor, and using leather would only allow it to be used on leather armor. The one exception I feel is that using diamonds should still allow the template to be applied to netherite armor the way it currently does, as no one wants to spend a ton of netherite ingots just to duplicate one template.

In this way players wouldn't have to break the bank to trim their less valuable gear, but there would still be a reasonable cost to doing so for the rare stuff.

Does searching the world for Smithing Templates feel adventurous?

  • Armor trims being exclusive to specific biomes is one of the only truly adventurous things being added to Minecraft.  By definition, it is largely inaccessible yet coveted, it's unique and requires exploration. It requires adventure. This is great. The world needs reasons to be explored at the micro level. Chests filled with bread and ingots are extremely underwhelming and most loot can be found naturally or boringly, through villager trading. The only thing quite like armor trims are jukebox discs, horse armor. and the elytra. 
  • I would greatly encourage the Minecraft team to continue to add things like this, where there is no game function or purpose and is purely to be stumbled across, such as animal variants, unique paintings, make some enchantment books unique, etc.

Here is my feedback. Could some of the templates could be enchanted when you find them(And could be applied to armor when trimmed), and maybe they could even be aquired by fishing? Along with applying this to Horse Armor, Elytras, and MAYBE weapons and tools as well??? It was just a thought that if it's purely cosmetic, it can be boring. And this has to go to other armors as well. Some of the smithing templates could have their own unique set of uses as well. Like the Snout trim with gold could prevent piglins from attacking you? It could require a full set of Netherite Armor with the trim as well, but that's up to ya'll(Mojang/Microsoft).

The recipe to duplicate smiting templates is also quite expensive. Using 7 diamonds just seems a bit excessive and tedious.

Someone else had an idea that one trim template could be used infinitely, while diamond could then just be the cost to apply it. Armor trims should be a reward and a motive for exploration, so the value should be mainly in finding them.

I understand that there is an effort to increase the value of diamond, however I think that diamond just doesn't make sense as the cost in this case, since diamond has no world connection to how an armor trim would be applied. Gold, iron, and copper do make sense, as they more closely resemble quicksilver, which was used back in the days to add decoration to weapons and armor.

I also think that some of the armor trims are a bit too bold, since they go beyond simply adding customization and completely disfigure the appearance of the armor. The amount of pixels added from certain trims could be reduced, and the impact of patterns could be reduced so that the appearance of armor still remains intact and the aesthetic of the game is not completely blown out of the water.

Customization is a good thing, but I think that the devs should avoid disturbing the flow and aesthetic of the game by giving the players too much power. Playing Minecraft is an interaction between the player and the game, and just as the game should not be too restrictive on the player, as to make the game unplayable, the player should still be playing within a game with it's own restrictions and quirks, otherwise the game isn't making any interaction with the player.

I feel like too many of the patterns feel too similar to other patterns, ultimately leading to less customization potential. Would be nice too see trims play around with more shapes/concepts, instead of a bunch of variants of the Coast trim look. Specifically, I would love to see more vertical lines, organic shapes, wavy lines, zigzags, solid accent portions etc.

Also think certain armor sets have the issue of getting one trim design that stands out and looks really cool, but the other pieces don't really fit into any theme and are ultimately forgettable (looking at you, Ward and Eye). In general, even though all the trims are technically different, the difference of a lot of them is too minor to be worth mixing and matching them.

More distinct armor trims would also be good for colorblindness, as it would better help colorblind players distinguish other players by their armor trim patterns. A lot of the current designs might be mistaken for each other by colorblind players as it stands.

Also players would probably care more about seeking these out if they were more distinct. Being able to concretely tell where somebody got a trim from at first glance makes the specific trim you're using more of a status symbol. If the average player can't distinguish Coast and Spire, going all the way to an End City isn't all that worth it.

It's great how expressive the trims are. They're very cool cosmetics, but I'm concerned they don't add much value beyond just that. I propose that the armor trims be given more practical applications as well to encourage everyone to seek them out and collect as many as possible. I think this can be done by applying different small buffs or properties to armor trims depending on the material. The buffs would increase by the amount of armor the player wears, but mix-and-matching different materials on trims would encourage players to create many different sets and make their collection more worth-while. Some ideas I had per material are as follows:

Copper = reduces hit-stun / weapon cool-down
Iron = reduces received knockback
Gold = pacifies regular piglins / speed buff
Diamond = increases luck
Netherite = chance to nullify received damage on hit
Quartz = reduces range of mob detection
Amethyst = chimes on boots / glows in the dark
Lapis = gain extra exp
Redstone = chance to stun physical attackers on hit
Emerald = extra wandering trader items / jump buff

I love to see such a creative way to customize your character in the game, but... why do cosmetics cost so much to duplicate? Armor trims offer no extra buffs to your armor, so why use up seven whole diamonds to make your armor look cooler? Also, it is a Smithing *Template*. Templates are like stencils, and shouldn't be consumed upon use.

So I propose that either Armor Trims aren't consumed upon use, or they are easier to duplicate. The high price of duplication isn't beginner-friendly at all, and while I don't have a problem with branch mining for diamonds, some players might not have the time or patience to get enough diamonds to blow on a cosmetic option to begin with.

As for how to make Trim duplication easier, I have another two ideas; make the templates cheaper (maybe theee or four diamonds instead of seven), or get more trims per duplication to get more bang for your buck. Other than that, the idea of customizable armor is a good one, and I hope to see more unique trim designs as more structures and features are added.

Diamonds shouldn’t be used in a consumable fashion like this. Want to give more use to diamonds? Let’s talk stairs, slabs, cut/chiseled/smooth/whatever variants to decorate with. As blocks diamonds may not be renewable, but they at least remain reusable. If I wanted to burn diamonds quickly, finding a nearby pit of lava would be so much simpler.

Ditto for the netherite upgrade template. Seems silly to change the cost so dramatically for the upgrade long after introducing the itself. It is particularly unfair to newer players in older worlds. I was really looking forward to personalizing gear, but consumable templates just makes this the next phantom in my mind. Seriously, why even give us the option to trim leather/iron/chain/gold armor if it’s going to cost diamonds to duplicate the templates?

Also bear in mind that exploration is not free on realms. Forcing too much of it on a world easily leads to the size growing to the point of failure. In other words, further exploration to find additional copies of templates to burn is not a sustainable alternative and is actually quite harmful. Strip mining for diamonds has a similar effect.

Since the post I made is duplicate i'll explain the idea a tiny bit more :

 

As the user MANUEL_XXVI did on twitter, glowing armor trims would be an extremely good idea in my opinion, it would allow for even more possibilities for customizing your armor, it would give another use for the glow ink sac, and during the night you'll be able to spot people, even with the lowest brightness setting !

 

Here is the link to the original creator's tweet, showcasing his work :

https://twitter.com/Manuel_XXVI/status/1619077339085938688?s=20&t=9RC39qEcwv99TiNfOtxwIw

Notice : the showcase has been made with shaders but even with the vanilla glow effect the feature would be welcome

I’ve seen a lot of people request this, and this would be so cool!! It would also look really cool when you display armor on an armor stand, and people could use armor in other ways for decorations in a build, like if they used a helmet with glow trim to make a disco ball or something!
it would be nice

You can only upgrade an armor piece, that is colored with a trim.
Upgrading:

Glowing Armor trim + Armor + Glow Inc Sac = Glowing armor
